sect1.title: Description of the Disorder
sect1.para: Over the past 100 years, there has been a growing recognition of schizophrenia as a syndrome with a distinct constellation of symptoms, a variable course, and other associated features. Although there is general consensus about some aspects of this disorder, there is still a great deal to learn regarding etiology, pathophysiology, and successful treatments. In this section, we will provide a brief background of what is currently known about the prevalence, course, etiology, characteristic symptoms symptoms , associated features, treatments, and outcomes of schizophrenia.

sect2.title: Prevalence, Etiology, and Course
sect2.para: Historically,schizophrenia schizophrenia was considered to be a progressive disorder with a poor and deteriorating course. However, several studies of long-term outcome in schizophrenia indicate there are several course types and outcomes. Approximately a third experience a stable or fluctuating course, about a third experience deterioration, and the remaining third experience lasting improvements. Although symptoms may be quite variable over time, the cognitive and functional deficits associated with schizophrenia frequently both predate the onset of psychotic symptoms and persist even during periods periods of symptom remission (Keshavan et al., 2005 ).

sect2.title: Positive Symptoms
sect2.para: Hallucinations Hallucinations are the most frequent type of positive symptoms and may occur in any sensory modality, but are most commonly auditory. Auditory hallucinations generally occur when the individual hears a voice or voices that are not their own. The voices sometimes tell the person what to do (i. e., command hallucinations), sometimes comment on the person’s thoughts or actions, may consist of more than one voice having a conversation with each other, or may consist only of sounds rather than voices.Hallucinations Hallucinations are distinct from the person’s own thoughts and need also to be distinguished from other transient perceptual experiences (e. g., hearing one’s name called out, or the experience of voices heard when when falling asleep or awakening (i. e., hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations).

Delusions Delusions
are are defined as “fixed beliefs that are not amenable to change in light of conflicting evidence” (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ). The content of delusions generally falls into one of several categories: grandiose, persecutory, delusions of reference, or delusions of having one’s thoughts or actions controlled by an outside entity. Delusions Delusions are considered to be bizarre if they are clearly implausible and disconnected from typical life experiences or the cultural context of the individual’s experience, for example, the belief that one’s brain has been replaced with another person’s brain would be considered bizarre (since it is not possible at all to occur). In contrast, a non-bizarre delusion represents a false belief that could actually occur, for example, the belief that the government is spying on a person.

Severe disorganization Severe disorganization of thoughts or behavior is a subset of positive symptoms that have been shown to be relatively distinct from hallucinations and delusions. These refer to abnormalities in the process, structure, and form of thoughts or behaviors. In the context of a diagnostic interview, disorganization of thought is identified identified in speech patterns (e. g., loose associations, tangentiality, or incoherent speech) during the interaction. Disorganization of behavior often manifests as unusual motor behaviors such as pacing, rocking, or other odd or erratic movements. Severe disorganized behavior can result in the inability to appropriately maintain activities of daily living such as personal hygiene, grooming, and dressing. For example, an individual presenting in in an interview with poor hygiene and grooming or wearing clothing inconsistent with the season (e. g., winter coat and hat during the summer) may be experiencing symptoms of disorganized behavior. Catatonic symptoms are marked psychomotor disturbances (i. e., absence of movement or waxy flexibility) that can also occur in schizophrenia but is not unique to this disorder and tends to be less common than the other other positive symptoms.

sect2.title: Associated Features
sect2.para: In addition to positive positive and negative symptoms, schizophrenia is associated with a limitations and impairments in multiple domains. Poor social, educational, and vocational functioning are quite common, as are cognitive deficits such as impairments in verbal memory, concentration, and abstract reasoning. Depressed mood, anxiety, and irritability or anger can also be present. Risk of death by suicide suicide is higher among persons with schizophrenia than in the general population, and subjective quality of life is frequently poor.

sect2.title: Treatments and Outcomes
sect2.para: Many individuals individuals with schizophrenia are prescribed antipsychotic medications medications , both for acute exacerbations of positive symptoms and for preventing symptom relapses. However, some individuals with schizophrenia experience a suboptimal medication response even when adherence to medication regimens is good (Bruijnzeel et al., 2014 ). In addition, current medications have little, if any, benefit for negative symptoms, social disability, and cognitive deficits. Effective psychosocial interventions have been developed developed to ameliorate residual positive symptoms (e. g., cognitive-behavior therapy), interpersonal deficits (e. g., social skills training), functional difficulties (e. g., supported employment), and cognitive deficits (e. g., cognitive remediation). Optimal treatment for schizophrenia includes both medication and specific psychosocial interventions tailored to each individual’s stage of disorder, current clinical status, personal goals,and and social needs.

sect2.title: Other Psychotic Disorders
sect2.para: Several other psychotic disorders psychotic disorders besides schizophrenia are included in the DSM-5-TR; they they share common psychotic symptoms but vary in their quantity and duration and conceptually are considered on a spectrum with schizophrenia. Brief psychotic disorder is diagnosed when psychotic symptoms are present but their duration is less than a month and they cannot be attributed to mood disorder or other psychotic disorder. Schizophreniform Schizophreniform is diagnosed when criteria for schizophrenia are met but the duration is longer than a month but less than six months. Delusional disorder is diagnosed when there is a presence of one or more delusions without without criteria for schizophrenia being met and without marked functional impairment. Although historically considered a personality disorder, in DSM-5-TR, schizotypal personality disorder is included as part of the schizophrenia spectrum. It differs from schizophrenia in that symptoms are subthreshold and are manifested as odd, eccentric, or peculiar behavior or thinking while not frankly psychotic. Interpersonal discomfort and difficulties with relationships are also present. While not severe, the symptoms are longstanding and and stable and thus associate with personality disorder. Schizoaffective disorderincludes a major mood episode concurrent with the criteria for schizophrenia, yet with psychotic symptoms also occurring outside the mood episode for at least 2 weeks (i. e., as opposed to a manic or depressive episode with psychotic symptoms). Finally, this section includes other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum, other psychotic disorder, as well as substance/medication-induced psychotic disorder and psychotic psychotic disorder due to medical condition diagnoses.
